conclusion: To solve the problem, analyze the image to understand the flow path of liquid through the baffles and identify key connections to determine where the liquid will flow.

The image shows a series of containers (A, B, C, D) connected by pipes and baffles. Liquid can flow out of containers A, B, C, and D. There are three main container options: E, F, and G, connected to the flow path.
Stream A strikes the brown slanted barrier and is deflected to the right.
Stream B hits the purple slanted barrier and is deflected to the left.
Stream C and D impact the yellow baffle and turn left.

premise: Stream A strikes the brown slanted barrier and is deflected to the right.
conclusion: Liquid from A flows through a pipe connected to E.

premise: Stream B hits the purple slanted barrier and is deflected to the left.
conclusion: Liquid from B passes through a baffle connected to F.

premise: Stream C and D impact the yellow baffle and turn left.
conclusion: Liquid from C flows through a pipe leading to G.

premise: Stream C and D impact the yellow baffle and turn left.
conclusion: Liquid from D flows through a baffle leading to E.

premise: Liquid from A flows through a pipe connected to E and liquid from D flows through a baffle leading to E.
conclusion: Liquid from A and D ends up in E.

premise: Liquid from B passes through a baffle connected to F.
conclusion: Liquid from B ends up in F.

premise: Liquid from C flows through a pipe leading to G.
conclusion: Liquid from C ends up in G.

premise: Stream A and B mix up then encounter the blue baffle, turn right and meet with the mixture of Stream C and D.
conclusion: Most mixture of A, B, C and D ends in container F; a thin stream of mixture from A, B and C ends in container E; no stream ends in container G.
